data.title: Better HTML support for react
data.body:
Refs: #24403

Currently if my react component returns HTML I do not get any nice HTML support when I try to edit this, instead this code is treated as javascript.

Easy repro steps 
1. npm install -g create-react-app
2. create-react-app my-app
3. cd my-app/
4. code-insiders .
5. open app.js and try editing the HTML returned by the component

data.title: Update Exec param at code.desktop
data.body:
The `/usr/share/code/code/` path opens a new window with errors.
Adding bin to the path fixes it.

Fixes #10091

data.title: Debug hover does not use AST

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is a current limitation of the debug hover that it does not have a full language understanding and due to that tries to find the hovered expression in the variables view. If the hovered expression is not present in the variables view or has duplicates the hover will not show anything.

To improve this the debug hover would need to have an AST understanding of the language which is a feature request and not yet on the plan.

An alternative is that a debug adapter extension can choose to evaluate expressions on hover but this has the downside of potentially mutating the state of the program without the user being aware. Currently node debug is not doing this.

data.title: Git integration disappears in second and subsequently opened windows in 1.11.1
data.body:
Git integration has disappeared for multiple windows in the latest version. VS code now shows no Git content at all for second and subsequent concurrently opened windows.

~~Git integration has disappeared for submodule projects in the latest version. I am not talking about supporting them as submodules - that has never existed, I'm talking about being able to independently open the folder of a submodule project and do Git operations on that project alone. VS code now shows no Git content at all for these projects.~~

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open Visual Studio Code.
2. Open a folder for which Git is enabled.
3. Open a second Visual Studio Code window.
4. Open a folder for which Git is enabled.
5. Check for a checkout name in the bottom left or anything relevant in the Git window.

Git output window shows:
Using git 2.7.4 from git
git rev-parse --show-toplevel
git rev-parse --show-toplevel
git rev-parse --show-toplevel
git rev-parse --show-toplevel

data.title: Unable to <alt> keybindings that match top level menus

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.1 (d9484d12b38879b7f4cdd1150efeb2fd2c1fbf39, 2017-04-06T13:55:56.395Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-72-generic
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|markdown-toc|AlanWalk|1.5.1|
|numbered-bookmarks|alefragnani|0.7.0|
|project-manager|alefragnani|0.13.5|
|code-gnu-global|austin|0.2.1|
|togglehs|bbenoist|0.1.2|
|vscode-markdownlint|DavidAnson|0.7.1|
|jshint|dbaeumer|0.10.15|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.2.0|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.0|
|gitlens|eamodio|3.3.3|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.6.5|
|git-project-manager|felipecaputo|1.2.1|
|Angular2|johnpapa|2.2.3|
|vscode-clang|mitaki28|0.2.2|
|HTMLHint|mkaufman|0.3.3|
|prettify-json|mohsen1|0.0.3|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.10.5|
|Spell|seanmcbreen|0.9.1|
|code-settings-sync|Shan|2.6.2|
|cmake|twxs|0.0.17|
|cmake-tools|vector-of-bool|0.9.4|
|clang-format|xaver|1.2.1|;


---

I am unable to successfully use <alt> based keybindings that match the top level menus. 

I have the following custom key shortcuts
alt + D = delete line
alt + G = go to line

However when I press the key sequences the corresponding menu bar menus are shown instead of my bound shortcut actions, e.g.
alt + d = Debug menu
alt + g = Go menu

I have tried setting "window.menuBarVisibility": "hidden" but that appears to have no effect. 
I have had some success disabling the setting "Key to show the menu bar while pressed"  under Desktop > Ubuntu Unity Plugin in the "CompizConfig Settings Manager" application.  With this setting set to Disabled my alt key binding work in VSCode when it is initially launched but the behavior reverts after  to another application and then back to VSCode.

Steps to Reproduce:

1.
2.

data.title: "Configure Task Runner" should pick tasks from package.json
data.body:
**Refs:** Vue.js test tour (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/23385)

When selecting "Configure Task Runner" and the package.json inside the project already has scripts configured for run, test, build etc. I think we should take those scripts automatically into the launch.json.

data.title: Debug: "Select script" picker should show a little more

**Refs:** Vue.js test tour (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/23385)

When debugging a vue.js application using the Chrome Debugger, the script picker showed cryptic names making it hard to find the actual script to debug:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/24912457/7065c48a-1ece-11e7-889d-5475cb78850f.png)

Not sure if that is a debug issue or extension issue though.

data.title: [Regression] No longer get window.onDidChangeActiveTextEditor events when there is no window.activeEditor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.1 (d9484d12b38879b7f4cdd1150efeb2fd2c1fbf39, 2017-04-06T14:00:34.044Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0

---

I'm not exactly sure when this changed, but I used to get the `window.onDidChangeActiveTextEditor` event when there is no active editor -- i.e. closing all documents/tabs, switching to say an extension page (where there is no text editor). The event would just have an `undefined` editor parameter, but now I no longer seems to fire at all.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open an extension that listens for `window.onDidChangeActiveTextEditor`
2. Observe that no event will be raised when you close the last editor, nor when you switch to an extension page

This is causing issues in GitLens (https://github.com/eamodio/vscode-gitlens/issues/65 is one) since I am not getting the event anymore to properly update my tracking. This has also broken https://github.com/eamodio/vscode-restore-editors for the same reason.

/cc @jrieken

This also happens if you select 'Peek Definition' and double click in the output to open the file.

data.title: "Go to File" in editor group command
data.body:
I often want the "Go to File" command, but only for editors currently open in the group. This is useful when you have lots of editors open in a group.

The standard "Go to File" command provides a search for all files, so is too noisy for this.

The "Open Next Recently Used Editor in Group" command provides a list of all files open in the group, but there's no interface to search it.

I propose a "Go to File in Group" command.

data.title: export settings/ user profile (feature request)
data.body:
I was using Mac for development for almost 5-6 months with VSCODE and now I'm moving to a new laptop. Its really helpful if I can import/export or sync my installed extensions with user profile so I do not need to install all of them one by one and other customisation I have done.

Note: It is a feature request and not a issue

data.title: Dark icons and colors shown in light themes
data.body:
Not clear what the reproducible steps are, but @alexandrudima both seen it after a update: Light themes with dark icons and some other dark colors shining though in a light theme.

Debugging this I saw that both the 'vs' and the 'vs-dark' classes are set.
Bug is in the workbenchThemeService. When applying the persisted colors, the 'vs' and the 'vs-dark' classes are not cleared.
